summary: the vacuolar-type H+-ATPase (v-ATPase) is the major proton pump responsible for acidification of intracellular compartments in eukaryotic cells. the enzyme consists of two multi-subunit complexes, the soluble V1 subcomplex catalyzing ATP hydrolysis and the transmembrane Vo subcomplex required for the proton transport across membranes. the function of v-ATPases is essential for cellular processes such archazolids are natural compounds of high interest that can be used both as a tool to study the consequences of v-ATPase inhibition. they can be either produced by fermentation [11] or by total synthesis [13,14]. archazolid activated pathways of cellular stress response and apoptosis in highly invasive tumor cells. the inhibition of v-ATPase by concanamycin prevented proliferation, reduced migration and impaired angiogenesis-related signaling in endothelial cells. a link between the function of v-ATPases and the adhesion and transmigration properties of endothelial cells. both types of endothelial cells were cultivated in collagen G-coated flasks or seeded into collagen G-coated cells. human breast cancer cell line MDA-MB-231 (ACC-732) and prostate cancer cell line PC-3 (ACC-465) were obtained from the leibniz Institute DSMZ-German Collection of microorganisms and cell cultures (Braunschweig, Germany) all cell types were cultivated at 37°C and 5% CO2. the assay is based on the ability of metabolically active cells to reduce resazurin. 1 g/ml Hoechst 33342 (Sigma-Aldrich, Munich, Germany) was used to visualize the nuclei. 50 nM LysoTracker Red DND-99 was used to visualize the acidic compartments which correspond to the lysosomes. both dyes were incubated for 10 min at 37°C before acquisition of single images. treated HUVECs, MDA-MB-231 or PC-3 cells were washed once with DMEM. for blocking the integrin 1 subunit on HUVECs, cells were incubated with the anti-integrin 1 antibody (0.1 g/well in ECGM) transmigration was quantified by measuring fluorescence signal at 485 nm (excitation) and 535 nm (emission) the cells were induced to upregulate the gene expression of cell adhesion molecules by TNF. the threshold cycle of the target = 3). PC-3 cells were allowed to adhere for 60 min. blocking of the integrin 1 subunit on MDA-MB-231 and PC-3 cells abolished the interaction with collagen. Fig 7 shows that the attachment of these tumor cells to collagen is mediated by 1-integrins. a representative image out of three independently performed experiments is shown. the increase in extracellular collagen was quantified. data are expressed as mean SEM (n = 3) western blot analysis showed that archazolid reduces the activity and expression of cathepsin B in endothelial cells. the activity of cathepsin B was strongly decreased by approximately 50% compared to control cells at an archazolid concentration of 1 nM. overexpression of cathepsin B in endothelial cells attenuates both the basal and archazolid-induced adhesion of MDA-MB-231 cells. the adhesion was quantified by measuring the fluorescence signal using a plate reader. archazolid-induced tumor cell adhesion was mediated by 1-integrins expressed on MDA-MB-231 breast cancer and PC-3 prostate cancer cells. adhesion of non-metastatic Jurkat cells was largely independent from extracellular matrix proteins. jurkat cells express 41-integrins but lack 21-, 31-integrins [44] Jurkat cells interact with human endothelial cells that express VCAM-1 after cytokine treatment. 21- and 31-integrins expressing MDA-MB-231 and PC-3 cells were not able to adhere [44] and might preferentially interact with cell adhesion molecules rather than with ECM proteins. v-ATPase inhibition impairs cathepsin B activity in endothelial cells. v-ATPase inhibition impaired cathepsin B activity in endothelial cells. archazolid-induced decrease in cathepsin B activity and expression. the adhesion of Jurkat cells is mostly independent from the ECM proteins collagen, fibronectin or laminin. archazolid-induced MDA-MB-231 cell adhesion onto the endothelium resulted in a decrease in transendothelial migration. v-ATPase plays an important role in regulating the adhesion of cells expressing receptors for extracellular matrix components. archazolid represents a promising tool to elucidate the role of v-ATPase in
